bibl.title: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, June 13, 1900

div1.p: Louise Kean writes about daily life in Cuba and cases of yellow fever in Havana and on the Post.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, June 13, 1900
div1.p:
The things from
Sterns came early yes-
terday morning, and
I got your letter this
morning, for father, with
great presence of wind,
concealed it on the
hall mantle- piece be-
fore he went to town
Tuesday morning. How-
ever it made no dif-
ference and the things
are lovely. I was so
surprised and delighted
with my kimono, and
it seems to me it was
very cheap for such a
lovely one. Helen and I
went into raptures over
the baby's coat, which
is certainly much more
ornamental, if not quite
as useful as the two
outing flannel wrappers
you made me put on
the list, insisting that
a coat was quite un-
necessary.

Helen's room is being
fumigated today, for
we could not get the
lamp any sooner, and I am expect-
ing Mr. Meeker any minute to take
down the wooden bed, and put up
the fine, new iron one that is
standing in the hall. The mattress
is promised for today. Helen had
to go into town today to lunch
with Miss Gray, so Marie and I
are running the house to suit our-
selves. Helen is likewise to do some
errands in town, in which you
would probably not take any interest
so I won't tell you what they are.
I went to market this morning
and bought two money orders to
send Doll. One for ten pesos for Miss
Cochrane and one for fifteen for Doll
herself. Father had some five compli-
cated scheme of bank drafts, express
orders etc., but my brain being unused
to such refinements I e was so com-
monplace as to cash
his check and buy two
money-orders, which I
will have in the mail
before the Gov. returns
from town. A letter
came from Tom saying
he would leave for
St. Louis on the 9th and
would write from there
the exact date of his
arriving at home. I
don't know if father
sent the letter on to
you, but he will tele-
graph you as soon as
Tom writes again.

I got two letters from
Rannie last night.
If it was not for
our dear, little General
Rannie's leave would
have been a thing of
the distant future,
for Gen. Wood disap-
proved it for the present.
When Rannie to showed
it to the General he
told him not to write
me about it, and he
climbed into his bug-
gy and drove down to
see Gen. Wood. He finally
fixed it, so that if the fever is
stamped out Rannie can take his
leave at the end of the month, and
our General is to decide. Isn't he
the dearest most kind hearted old
gentleman? They have had eleven
cases so far, only one from the post,
the rest from one place on the calzada
about 100 yds. square between Gen. Lee
St. and Maceo, and Rannie's last letter
said things were looking much brighter,
so I trust no new foci will appear.
I met Mrs. Gamble up town today
and we had a most friendly and
affectionate chat. The boys are well
and cheerful, and everything is run-
ning smoothly, the new handmaiden
being very superior, likewise strong and
willing. Don't work too hard Mumsie
and I am quite provoked at you for taking
any sewing with you.
div1.closer: Most lovingly Louise. Teeter has quite a bad case of fever, but Rannie thinks he will get well.
